metadata.name: Breakers #41
metadata.description:
Companion project to Neural Collapse (#15780), for the collectors of my previous efforts.
A study on the repetition and stacking of a simple dynamic structure, this time inside a cylinder.

Everything procedurally generated at runtime.

Interactivity : 
- You can click on each individual breaker to open or close them. The problem is it will toggle others.
- Press and hold the mouse button to slightly move the viewpoint. The previous interaction not being disabled while doing that, you get some switching all over the place as a bonus bug/feature.

- Press "a" to increase quality of the antialiasing (3 levels), at the cost of performances. If you don't like jaggies and your machine can take it.
- Export a PNG capture at various resolutions by pressing the number keys 1 to 9 (top row or numpad, and only in live mode, after pressing "open"). Resolutions ranges from 720 to 7680 pixels. I recommend starting with "4".

GPU recommended. Best performances on Chrome in general.

metadata.name: Repose #367
metadata.description:
The art is programmatically drawn using basic shapes, math, random using p5js.

To save image:

press 's' or '0' to save in default quality
press 'd' or '7' to save in high quality and 
press 'f' to see art in full screen.
Hello everyone, the time is 12.59, but now, it is 1:00.

metadata.name: Raster Colonies #17
metadata.description: Cube heights are set by fractal Brownian motion then colored based on height

metadata.name: Droplet #1
metadata.description:
Droplet began as something else, and here we are. 

Abstract drops dripping on different dimensions and colors.

Created with p5js and noise.

Press '1', '2', or '4' to change pixelDensity(). Defaults to 1 x dimensions.
Press 's' to save jpeg.

VGA 2022 - License: CC BY-NC 4.0

metadata.name: Unicorn #4250
metadata.description:
All of us have dreams, and everyone would like to meet a fairy, a genie, a wizard, or someone else who will make our dreams come true in a snap of a finger or with the wave of a wand. But we're the only ones who can do it. We are those magical unicorns, unique, inimitable, with our own qualities and magical abilities.
These unicorns are the visualization of our inner selves that makes our dreams come true. An embodiment of all the best with a huge positive magical power.

Twitter: @unicorn_nft_art
Web: https://unicorn-nft.web.app/

by @lucky26puch, @AgataBaranova17
Made in 2022

License: CC BY-NC 4.0

metadata.name: Typing #201
metadata.description: This project is intentionally released anonymously to emphasize the art rather than the artist. I hope you enjoy!

metadata.name: Fever Dream Fairy Fantasy Forest #123
metadata.description:
A strange place where you can't tell the trees from the sky, the clouds from the shrubs, or where your body ends and the ground begins.

Press [s] in live view to capture a 2048x2048 screenshot



XALTED 2022

metadata.name: Plottable Thousands #121
metadata.description:
'Thousands' explores the packing of recursive circles and golden angle spirals distributing various particles on a A4 canvas.

A SVG file can be exported (right click save) to plot the piece physically.

You can enjoy the digital version that simulate ink effects and optional, thanks to the utility token decoupling, get a physical one: the digital NFT is the recipe to a plottable art piece, owning it confers the right to plot or request a physical plot from @greweb (https://greweb.me/plots/nft). @greweb would use fountain pens but other plotting artists are free to achieve it with their own materials and ship to collectors – as long as NFT is owned at request time.

Code: https://github.com/gre/gre/tree/master/doodles/plottable-thousands

@greweb – 2022 – tech: WebGL + Rust + WASM – CC BY-SA 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/

metadata.name: Polar Grid #419
metadata.description:
Polar Grid is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022.

This is a study of color, motion, and composition, and an homage to cinema as an artform. Colorful shapes overlap and pulse in a ever repeating dance. An abstracted movie experience. Each color palette in the series (except one) is inspired by a different film director (if you want a real challenge, see how many you can guess without looking at the feature names).

The palettes were extracted from movie stills or movie posters and fine tuned by hand. As often, I have to thank independent tool makers for their indirect help. My gratitude goes to David Aerne for FarbVélo and Fabrizio Bianchi for Coolors.

The code for Polar Grid is based on early iterations of what ultimately became my carat series. Both projects come from the same fascination for color as a system, even though I used a different approach here. You could call this a carat prequel.

The animation is done using a technique called polar noise. This makes it so the motion of all elements ends up repeating in the same amount of time. This is useful for generating motion that loops perfectly while still appearing organic. In this particular case, the animation repeats every π × 100 seconds.

A challenge in building any generative system is to find the right balance between coherence and variety. I designed the system with the large edition size in mind. During development I generated hundreds of iterations and tweaked my code to make sure that every iteration is truly unique and fits the overall aesthetic of the collection.

I truly hope you will enjoy your own little abstract movie.

— Raphaël de Courville


Released: July 6th 2022

Medium: p5.js, html canvas, css

Reference: sk220621


**About the artist**

Raphaël de Courville is a generative artist, streamer, and educator. His artistic work is an exploration of generative systems, patterns, interactivity, and time. Born in Paris, he lives and works in Berlin.


**Instructions**

- Click/Tap or press SPACEBAR to play and pause the animation

In Fullscreen mode (desktop only):
- Press UP or DOWN arrows to adjust image quality (Note: this can affect performance)
- Press F to hide/show the browser UI

metadata.name: ASCII-SCAPE #160
metadata.description:
ASCII-SCAPE

Like for many others growing up during the 1980s & 90s, my very first hands-on encounter with actual computer graphics (outside of games) was in the form of "textmode" and its various alphanumeric characters and other symbols available on the 8bit home computers of that period. These machines were perfectly capable of producing fairly high-resolution & multi-color graphics (all relative), yet most systems booted into an interactive prompt with the so-called textmode as de-facto standard environment, providing a level, if also limited, playing field for the creation of text-based graphics from a patchwork of characters & symbols of a predefined font (system or custom). As is so often the case, limitation is the mother of invention and the regular, monospaced grid and standardized set of characters quickly encouraged an entire subculture of specialized designers & artists to emerge (which is currently being re-discovered & remixed by younger generations), applying & showcasing their creativity (with often surprisingly ingenious skills) in the form of game designs, user interfaces, disk mags, demoscene productions, competitions, flyers, BBSes and even various early Web designs of the mid/late 90s.

ASCII-SCAPE is an attempted non-nostalgic homage to these roots & culture. It is also a textmode-only (no canvas!) rework of my previous piece C-SCAPE. It combines my love of cellular automata with the stripped back aesthetics & limitations of using only text as representation medium of these co-evolving generative systems. It required an almost complete rewrite & re-curation of various elements: 1200+ new handpicked rule combinations, 32 character sets, 40 color themes, new relationships & biases to better manage the resulting textures, densities and contrast.

Although technically not strictly "ASCII" (an actual standard, but also a popular shorthand for "text only"), the entire simulation only uses various Unicode characters and the beautiful Iosevka open source typeface by Renzhi Li aka Belleve Invis.

Like its parent C-SCAPE, this project is dynamic and evolves indefinitely. It's best viewed on non-mobile devices, where there's a decent horizontal resolution to provide sufficient simulation space. Please see the C-SCAPE project description for further details. There's no graphical export feature, but output can be captured into an UTF-8 plain text file (max. 100k lines/generations).

The following keyboard shortcuts are available:

- space : toggle simulation updates (pause/play)
- r : randomize environment
- x : start/stop recording
- f : toggle scroll speed (fast/slow)

License

https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/

Iosevka typeface licensed under OFL-1.1 license

https://github.com/be5invis/Iosevka

Disclaimer

Minting this project will not guarantee inclusion in access lists for future projects.

Credits

Made in 2022 with <3 and https://thi.ng
